wikitext.*:
{{stub}}
'''William "Bill" Cater''' (1924 - 2020)<ref>Jill Rawlins, [https://pressgazette.co.uk/news/former-sunday-times-magazine-assistant-editor-bill-cater-dies-at-95/ Former Sunday Times Magazine assistant editor Bill Cater dies at 95], ''PressGazette'', 6 May 2020, updated 30 September 2022.</ref> was a British journalist who interviewed [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] on [[2 August]] [[1966]] for the ''[[wikipedia:Daily Express|Daily Express]]''.<ref>[[Wayne G. Hammond|Hammond, Wayne G.]] and [[Christina Scull|Scull, Christina]], ''[[The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]: Chronology'', p. 671</ref> Cater later became a friend of Tolkien {{redlink|<ref>[http://www.lotrplaza.com/forum/forum_posts.asp?TID=224896 Tolkien - the most unmanageable man (January 11, 2008)] at Lotrplaza.com, as of July 28, 2010</ref>}} '''and they exchanged several letters. In 1977, Cater made an interview with [[Christopher Tolkien]], concerning  the publication of ''[[The Silmarillion]]''.

In a 1972 article celebrating Tolkien's upcoming 80th birthday, Cater coined a famous expression which was to be used on the dustwrappers of an edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'':

{{quote|The English-speaking world is divided into those who have read The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings and those who are going to read them.|William Cater, The Sunday Times (UK)}}

He presented a paper called ''"Interviewing Tolkien" '' at the [[J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference]] in 1992, but it was not submitted for later publication in [[Proceedings of the J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference|the conference's proceedings]].<ref>[[Proceedings of the J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference]], p. 6</ref>
